text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.75.36, Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures, Procedures for Processing Technical Advice Cases.
MATERIAL CHANGES
plainlanguage.gov. (
) All references to “EO Manager, Examination Programs and Review” (EPR), becomes, FSL/ET Manager. (
) All references to “Audit” and “Auditing” is changed to “Examination” and “Examining”. (
) This IRM incorporates IG memo TEGE-
; Reissuance: Procedures Following the Reorganization, dated April
) Updated references to all rev. procedures throughout the manual section to reﬂect the latest date issuance.

) “Proceedings before the IRS” include: • The examination of a taxpayer’s return. • The consideration of a taxpayer’s claim for credit or refund. • Any matter under examination or in Appeals pertaining to tax-exempt bonds, tax credit bonds, or mortgage credit certiﬁcates. • Any other matter involving a speciﬁc taxpayer under the jurisdiction of Director. states that the primary objective of the EO program is regulatory, with emphasis on continued qualiﬁcation of exempt or- ganizations. IRM
) IRC

gives examiners the authority to: a. Examine any books, papers, records or other data necessary to an examination (includes electronic media). b. Issue a summons for information necessary to complete an c. Take testimony under oath to secure additional information needed. d. Ask about any offense connected to administering or enforcing the Internal Revenue laws. (
) During an examination, agents are responsible for determining if the tion: a. Meets the requirements for exemption. b. Has the proper foundation status (IRC
) organizations only). c. Filed all required tax and information returns. d. Reported information and tax liabilities correctly. (
) Agents are also responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC

Field Counsel - Any attorney in the TE/GE Division Field Counsel’s group who is assigned to a particular case.

) Rev. Proc.
, updated annually, deﬁnes a TAM as “advice furnished by an Associate office in a memorandum that responds to any request, under (Rev. Proc.

), for assistance on any technical or procedural question that develops during any proceeding before the IRS. The question must be on the interpretation and proper application of any legal authority, including legislation, tax treaties, court decisions, regulations, notices, rulings, revenue procedures, or announcements to a speciﬁc set of facts that concerns the treatment of an item in a tax period under examination or in Appeals.” (
) Proceedings before the IRS include: (
) the examination of a taxpayer’s (
) the consideration of a taxpayer’s claim for credit or refund; (
) any other matter involving a speciﬁc taxpayer under the jurisdiction of a Director. (
) Technical advice does not include any oral legal advice or any written legal advice furnished to the ﬁeld office that is not submitted and processed under Rev. Proc.
) The ﬁeld office or taxpayer may request a TAM when the application of the to the facts involved is unclear. (
) You may raise an issue in any tax period, even if a TAM was furnished for same or similar issue for another tax period.
Rev. Proc.
, updated annually, deﬁnes a TAM as “advice furnished by an Associate office in a memorandum that responds to any request, submitted under (Rev. Proc.

), for assistance on any technical or procedural question that develops during any proceeding before the IRS. The question must be on the interpretation and proper application of any legal authority, including legislation, tax treaties, court decisions, regulations, notices, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, or announcements to a speciﬁc set of facts that concerns the treatment of an item in a tax period under examination or in Appeals.”
You may raise an issue in any tax period, even if a TAM was furnished for the same or similar issue for another tax period.

Notify the taxpayer of your intent to request technical advice. For a sample of the 10 day notice of intent letter, see Exhibit 4.75.36-1.
Prepare, (with the assistance of Counsel), a statement of the issues, facts, law, and arguments supporting the IRS’ position and include it with the notice of
Strive to reach agreement on the facts and speciﬁc points at issue.
Exempt Organizations Examination (
) The taxpayer has no authority to bar your decision to seek technical advice; however, consider and document their objections. (
) A taxpayer may request, orally or in writing, that an issue be referred for technical advice. for (
) The taxpayer should submit the request to you. (
) You must discuss the request with your group manager. (

) If you and the group manager, (with the consent of the Area Manager), that a taxpayer’s request for a TAM is unwarranted, notify the taxpayer of decision. Note: You shouldn’t deny a taxpayer’s request for technical advice based solely the fact Associate Counsel has already provided legal advice other than a TAM on the matter. (
) For general TAM guidelines on instruction to the taxpayer refer to IRM
) The taxpayer may appeal the Field Office’s denial of their TAM request. (
) Within

calendar days after being notiﬁed that their request was denied, Field taxpayer should submit a written statement of the reasons why the matter of TAM should be referred to Associate Counsel. The statement must include: • An explanation of the need for technical advice. • A description of all pertinent facts (including any facts in dispute). • A statement of the issue that the taxpayer would like to have • A discussion of any relevant legal authority including legislation, tax treaties, case law, and other authorities. • An explanation of the taxpayer’s position. Note: Any extensions of the
-day period must be requested in writing and approved by the EO Exam Director. The Director’s decision is ﬁnal and not be appealed. (
) Upon receipt, forward the taxpayer’s written statement, along with your statement of why the issue shouldn’t be referred for technical advice, to the EO Exam Director. (
) The EO Exam Director determines if the issue should be referred for advice based on your statements and the taxpayer’s; no conference is held with the taxpayer/representative. (

) If the EO Exam Director determines that a TAM isn’t warranted, the EO office notiﬁes the taxpayer (along with the examiner/group manager) in of the proposed denial and the reasons (unless doing so would prejudice Government’s interests). (
) The taxpayer may not appeal the EO Exam Director’s decision. (

) Although the taxpayer cannot appeal the EO Exam Director’s decision a TAM request, the taxpayer may request a review by the Director, Exempt Organizations and Government Entities.. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) A pre-submission conference is mandatory for all TAM requests. If you a request for technical advice before a pre-submission conference is held, Associate Counsel will return it. (

) A pre-submission conference helps the parties involved discuss and agree • Background information. • Documents that should be included in the formal submission of the request for technical advice. • The appropriate scope of the request for technical advice. • The framing of the issues. (

) A pre-submission conference is held with: a. Associate Counsel attorney b. Field Counsel attorney c. Examiner d. Group manager e. Area Manager f. Taxpayer/representative Note: You may proceed with your requests for technical advice even taxpayer declines to participate in a pre-submission conference. (
) Counsel may raise new issues during the pre-submission conference. (
) Neither party is allowed to record the conference.
4.75.36.5 (06-08-2017) Pre-Submission Conference
Note: You may proceed with your requests for technical advice even if a taxpayer declines to participate in a pre-submission conference.
Counsel may raise new issues during the pre
submission conference. Neither party is allowed to record the conference. Before requesting a pre

submission conference, you must exchange proposed statements of the pertinent facts and issues with the taxpayer. The proposed statements should include: a. Any facts in dispute. b. The issues the parties intend to discuss. c. Legal analysis and supporting authorities. d. Any other background information believed to be useful.

Procedures for Processing Technical Advice Cases 4.75.36 page 7
c. Applicable law, and d. Supporting arguments for both you and the taxpayer (
) Include a discussion of: • Relevant statutory provisions • Tax treaties • Court decisions • Regulations • Revenue rulings • Revenue procedures • Notices • Other authorities (
) Include an explanation of disagreement on any facts between you and the taxpayer. (
) Both you and the taxpayer must comment on any authorities contrary to respective positions. Make note if none are found. (
) Once prepared, send a draft of the memorandum of facts, law, and to the taxpayer by mail or fax for comment and review. (
) The taxpayer has
calendar days to provide a written statement any disagreement on the facts and issues. Note: If the taxpayer needs more than

calendar days to respond, he/she submit a written request for extension to you. If an extension is warranted, secure group manager approval and notify the taxpayer as soon as The extension request is considered denied unless you inform the otherwise. Your decision is ﬁnal and can’t be appealed. (
) After you receive the taxpayer’s response, the parties have
calendar to resolve remaining disagreements. (
) If all disagreements are resolved, prepare a single statement of the agreed facts and issues. (

) If disagreements continue, prepare a statement that highlights the material factual differences and provide a copy of the statement to the taxpayer for review. Note: The taxpayer’s statement of facts and issues must be accompanied by following penalties of perjury statement: “Under penalties of perjury, I that I have examined this information, including accompanying and, to the best of my knowledge and belief, the information contains all relevant facts relating to the request for technical advice, and such facts true, correct, and complete.” This declaration must be signed by the taxpayer, not the representative. See Rev. Proc.
section for requirements. (
) The text of TAMs and background ﬁle documents are open to public under IRC

If the taxpayer needs more than 10 calendar days to respond, he/she must submit a written request for extension to you. If an extension is warranted, secure group manager approval and notify the taxpayer as soon as possible. The extension request is considered denied unless you inform the taxpayer otherwise. Your decision is ﬁnal and can’t be appealed.

b. Signed and dated by the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s authorized tative. A stamped signature or faxed signature isn’t permitted. (
) If the taxpayer wants only names, addresses, and identifying numbers they should state this in the deletion statement. (

) If the taxpayer wants more information deleted they must provide both a: a. Copy of the TAM request and supporting documents on which they placed brackets around the material to be deleted and b. Statement giving the statutory basis under IRC
(c) for each proposed deletion. (
) Notify the taxpayer the deletion statement is required. (
) If the taxpayer doesn’t provide the deletion statement within
calendar of the notice, inform Associate Counsel. Advise Associate Counsel of any mation in addition to names, addresses, and identifying numbers that be deleted. (
) The deletion statement requirements don’t apply if the TAM is open to inspection under IRC

, Return of Organization Exempt From Income Tax. You identify two issues in the examination. The ﬁrst is an exemption issue involving private beneﬁt through Z’s complex part- nership arrangement. return should remain in AIMS status

return to AIMS status

) The Associate Counsel attorney assigned to the TAM request will give frequent status updates. Keep the taxpayer/representative informed of any updates. Contact the taxpayer/representative at least quarterly. (
) Only the EO Exam Director may withdraw the request for a TAM after Associate Counsel receives the request. The Director sends a memorandum to Associate Counsel to request the withdrawal.

If the 20th day falls on a weekend or holiday, then enter the next business day. Last date to petition Tax Court Enter the 60th day after the date of mailing the notice. If the 60th day falls on a weekend or holiday, then enter the next business day (IRC 7503; T.C. Rule 25. Date Open to Public Inspection Enter the Friday preceding the 90th day after the date of mailing the notice. If that Friday falls on a holiday, then enter the previous business day. ) If the area manager agrees to protest the TAM, the agent immediately prepares a Memorandum of Request for Reconsideration addressed to Associate Counsel that signed the TAM in question. Include in the memoran- dum: a. The name and phone number of the agent. b. A signature block for the group manager (electronic signature c. A signature block for the area manager (electronic signature d. A description of the speciﬁc errors in the TAM analysis and Don’t re-argue points raised in the initial request. Instead focus on the TAM overlooked or misconstrued. Attach a copy of the TAM in question. e. Attach other pages from the technical advice case ﬁle that have a bearing on the issues or arguments that are being made in the request for reconsideration. (

,“ Suspense in Group”, unless there are certain other issues being developed. (

) The EOE Director’s staff forwards the reply and its attachments to the agent with instructions. (
) The agent updates the case to AIMS status
when he or she receives the reply with a re-issued TAM, or a conﬁrmation of the initial TAM in question. (

There will generally not be another request for reconsidera- tion (protest). (

on sending initial TAM and other documents to the taxpayer and to the Office of Chief Counsel for Disclosure. (

4.75.36-1 (01-14-2020) Letter of Intent (Custom Letter)
Dear [Insert name]

We’re requesting a Technical Advice Memorandum from the Office of Associate Chief Counsel (Associate Counsel) in connection with the examination of the return(s) for the period(s) shown above. We request Technical Advice from Associate Counsel when the application of the law to the facts involved is unclear or there’s no published precedent.
We have attached a statement of the facts, the applicable law, and our position on the issues for which we are seeking Technical Advice. See ATTACHMENT.

If you disagree with the facts as stated in the attachment, please respond to us in writing within 10 calendar days. The written statement should include an explanation of your position and the law that supports it. We also ask that you comment on any legislation, tax treaties, regulations, revenue rulings, revenue procedures, or court decisions contrary to your position. If you determine that there are no contrary authorities, please provide a statement to this effect. If you need more time to respond to this Letter of Intent, you must request it in writing and state your reasons.
16 4.75 Exempt Organizations Examination Procedures
Exhibit 4.75.36-1 (Cont. 1) (01-14-2020) 10-Day Letter of Intent (Custom Letter)

The text of Technical Advice Memoranda is open to public inspection under Internal Revenue Code (IRC) §6110(a). We delete certain information from the text before it’s made available to the public protect the privacy of taxpayers. To help us make the necessary deletions, you or your authorized sentative must provide a statement indicating the deletions desired. Under a letter of separate please indicate whether you request deletions other than names, addresses, and identifying you want additional deletions, the deletion statement must be accompanied by a copy of the facts, law, and position (yours and ours), on which you clearly bracket the information you want to delete. The deletion statement must indicate the speciﬁc paragraph under IRC §6110(c) upon which each deletion is based.

If you do not respond to this Letter of Intent, Associate Counsel may use the facts stated in the AT- TACHMENT and its accompanying exhibits to base a ruling. We will however present your arguments as we understand them. [If the issue is a declaratory judgment issue, include the following statement: “Because the issue(s) involved [is/are] subject to Declaratory Judgment under section 7428 of the Internal Revenue Code, we have attached a notice of Declaratory Judgment”]
If you have any questions, you can call me at the number indicated at the heading of this letter. Thank you for your cooperation.
Declaratory Judgement

IRC section 7428(a) of the Internal Revenue Code provides that the Tax Court, the United States Claims Court, or the District Court of the United States for the District of Columbia may make a declara- tion with respect to a continuing qualiﬁcation of an organization as an organization described in IRC section 501(c) or IRC 501(d) and exempt from taxation under IRC 501(a) in the case of actual contro- versy involving a determination by the Secretary.

Section 7428(b)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code provides that a declaratory judgment shall not be issued in any proceeding unless the Tax Court, the Claims Court, or the District Court of the United States for the District of Columbia determines that the organization involved has exhausted tive remedies available to it within the Internal Revenue Service.
for Processing Technical Advice Cases 4.75.36 page 17
